title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who sent messengers to David with timber of cedars and craftsmen to build him a house?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram king of Tyre
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:1 states that Hiram king of Tyre sent messengers to David with timber of cedars and masons and carpenters to build him a house.

questions.question: What did David perceive when the LORD confirmed him king over Israel?
options: His kingdom was lifted up on high because of his people Israel
He would defeat all his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: His kingdom was lifted up on high because of his people Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:2 says David perceived that the LORD had confirmed him king over Israel, and his kingdom was lifted up on high because of his people Israel.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 14:3, what did David do in Jerusalem?
options: Took more wives and begat more sons and daughters
Made a treaty with the Philistines
Led a battle against the Moabites
questions.correctAnswer: Took more wives and begat more sons and daughters
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:3 states that David took more wives at Jerusalem and begat more sons and daughters.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as one of David's children in 1 Chronicles 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:4-7 lists David's children in Jerusalem, and Absalom is not mentioned among them.

questions.question: Where did the Philistines spread themselves when they sought to fight David?
questions.correctAnswer: Valley of Rephaim
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:9 states that the Philistines spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

questions.question: What did David do before going out to battle the Philistines?
options: Enquired of God if he should go up against them
questions.correctAnswer: Enquired of God if he should go up against them
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:10 shows David enquiring of God whether he should go up against the Philistines and if God would deliver them into his hand.

questions.question: What name did David give to the place where God broke in upon his enemies like the breaking forth of waters?
questions.correctAnswer: Baalperazim
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:11 states that David called the place Baalperazim because God broke in upon his enemies there like the breaking forth of waters.

questions.question: What did David do with the gods the Philistines left behind after their defeat?
options: Commanded they be burned with fire
Sent them back to the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Commanded they be burned with fire
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:12 explains that David gave a commandment and the gods left behind were burned with fire.

questions.question: When the Philistines spread themselves again in the valley, what did God instruct David to do?
options: Go not up after them but come upon them over against the mulberry trees
questions.correctAnswer: Go not up after them but come upon them over against the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:14 records God telling David not to go up after the Philistines but to turn and come upon them opposite the mulberry trees.

questions.question: What sign was David to wait for before going out to battle the Philistines the second time?
options: A sound of going in the tops of the mulberry trees
A dove flying over the camp
questions.correctAnswer: A sound of going in the tops of the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:15 states that David was to go out to battle when he heard the sound of going in the tops of the mulberry trees.

questions.question: From where to where did David smite the host of the Philistines after following God's command?
questions.correctAnswer: From Gibeon even to Gazer
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:16 records that David smote the host of the Philistines from Gibeon even to Gazer.

questions.question: True or False: The fame of David went out into all lands because the LORD brought the fear of him upon all nations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:17 states that the fame of David went out into all lands and the LORD brought the fear of him upon all nations.

questions.question: True or False: David took fewer wives after he became king in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:3 states that David took more wives at Jerusalem, not fewer.

questions.question: True or False: The Philistines spread themselves in the valley of Jehoshaphat to seek David.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:9 says the Philistines spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim, not Jehoshaphat.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Chronicles 14:11: 'God hath broken in upon mine enemies by mine hand like the breaking forth of ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: waters
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:11 states that God broke in upon David's enemies like the breaking forth of waters.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 14 teach us about trusting God's guidance in difficult situations?
options: By seeking God's direction before going into battle
By relying on our own strength to win battles
By avoiding all conflicts to stay safe
By asking others instead of God for advice
questions.correctAnswer: By seeking God's direction before going into battle
questions.explanation: David inquired of God before fighting the Philistines and obeyed God's instructions, showing trust and dependence on divine guidance (1 Chronicles 14:10, 14, 16).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear before a challenge. Based on 1 Chronicles 14, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God delivers those who trust Him and goes before them
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
One must face challenges alone without asking God
Success depends solely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers those who trust Him and goes before them
questions.explanation: God promised to deliver David’s enemies and went before him to fight, teaching us to trust in God's power and protection (1 Chronicles 14:10, 15).

questions.question: What does David’s receiving help from Hiram king of Tyre teach about practical Christian living?
options: It shows the importance of building relationships and accepting help for God’s work
It shows that believers should only rely on themselves
It encourages isolation to avoid dependencies
It teaches that building projects are unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the importance of building relationships and accepting help for God’s work
questions.explanation: Hiram sent timber and craftsmen to David, demonstrating cooperation and stewardship in accomplishing God’s purposes (1 Chronicles 14:1).

questions.question: How does the passage illustrate the importance of obedience to God’s commands?
options: David obeyed God's specific instructions in battle and was victorious
David ignored God and acted on his own plans
David delayed action to test God’s patience
David relied on others to decide for him
questions.correctAnswer: David obeyed God's specific instructions in battle and was victorious
questions.explanation: David followed God's command to attack at the sound in the mulberry trees, resulting in victory, showing the blessing of obedience (1 Chronicles 14:14-16).

questions.question: What can we learn about humility and gratitude from David’s recognition of God’s help in battle?
options: David credited God for breaking his enemies like water breaking forth
David took all the glory himself
David boasted about his own strength
David ignored God’s role in the victory
questions.correctAnswer: David credited God for breaking his enemies like water breaking forth
questions.explanation: David named the place Baalperazim, acknowledging God's power in his victory, teaching us to be humble and grateful to God (1 Chronicles 14:11).

questions.question: A believer is considering adding to their family. What does 1 Chronicles 14 teach about family life?
options: David took more wives and had many children, reflecting blessing and responsibility
Family should not be a priority
questions.correctAnswer: David took more wives and had many children, reflecting blessing and responsibility
questions.explanation: David expanded his family, indicating the biblical value of family and parenting (1 Chronicles 14:3-7).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 14 demonstrate the importance of prayer and seeking God daily?
options: David inquired of God multiple times before and during conflict
David prayed only once and then acted by himself
David avoided prayer and relied on human advice
David ignored God's will in battle
questions.correctAnswer: David inquired of God multiple times before and during conflict
questions.explanation: David repeatedly sought God's guidance before making decisions, highlighting the need for continual prayer (1 Chronicles 14:10, 14).

questions.question: True or False: David’s victories in battle were a result of his own military skill alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David’s victories came because he sought and obeyed God’s guidance, showing dependence on divine help rather than his own skill (1 Chronicles 14:10-16).

questions.question: True or False: The fame of David and the fear of the LORD spread to all nations because of his faithfulness and God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David’s faith and God’s intervention caused his fame to spread and nations to fear the LORD (1 Chronicles 14:17).

questions.question: How does David’s handling of the Philistine gods demonstrate biblical stewardship and holiness?
options: David commanded the burning of the Philistine idols left behind
David kept the idols as trophies
David ignored the idols and left them
questions.correctAnswer: David commanded the burning of the Philistine idols left behind
questions.explanation: David ensured the destruction of foreign gods, showing commitment to holiness and stewardship of God’s honor (1 Chronicles 14:12).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When David heard a sound in the tops of the _____, he was to go out to battle because God had gone before him.
questions.correctAnswer: mulberry trees
questions.explanation: God instructed David to attack when he heard the sound in the tops of the mulberry trees, signaling God’s going before him (1 Chronicles 14:15).

questions.question: What does David’s acknowledgment that God had "confirmed him king" teach us about contentment and gratitude?
options: David recognized God’s hand in his elevated position and was content
David was discontent and sought more power
David ignored God’s role in his success
questions.correctAnswer: David recognized God’s hand in his elevated position and was content
questions.explanation: David perceived God's confirmation of his kingship and was thankful, teaching contentment and gratitude for God’s blessings (1 Chronicles 14:2).

questions.question: How does the chapter demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty in leadership?
options: David sought God’s will honestly before every major decision
David acted impulsively without consulting God
questions.correctAnswer: David sought God’s will honestly before every major decision
questions.explanation: David’s repeated inquiries to God before battle show his integrity and honest dependence on God’s guidance (1 Chronicles 14:10, 14).

questions.question: What biblical virtue is shown by David expanding his family in Jerusalem?
options: Faithfulness and responsibility in family life
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and responsibility in family life
questions.explanation: David’s additional wives and children reflect faithfulness to family responsibilities as part of God’s blessing (1 Chronicles 14:3-7).

questions.question: How does the chapter model perseverance through trials and challenges?
options: David faced repeated Philistine attacks but continually sought God and obeyed
David gave up after the first attack
David relied on his own strength only
questions.correctAnswer: David faced repeated Philistine attacks but continually sought God and obeyed
questions.explanation: Despite multiple threats, David trusted and obeyed God repeatedly, showing perseverance (1 Chronicles 14:8-16).

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 14.

questions.question: What material did Hiram king of Tyre send to David to help build his house, and what does this signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedars of Lebanon timber
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:1 states that Hiram sent timber of cedars, masons and carpenters. Cedar wood from Lebanon was highly prized in the ancient Near East for its durability and fragrance, symbolizing royal prestige and divine blessing in building projects.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 14, what was David's perception of his kingship after receiving support from Hiram king of Tyre?
options: The LORD had confirmed him king over Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD had confirmed him king over Israel
questions.explanation: Verse 2 explains David perceived that the LORD had confirmed him king, indicating divine approval rather than mere political power, highlighting the theological theme of God's sovereignty over kingship.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as one of David's children born in Jerusalem in 1 Chronicles 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom
questions.explanation: Verses 4-7 list David’s children in Jerusalem, including Shammua, Nathan, and Solomon, but Absalom is not mentioned here, though he appears in other biblical texts such as 2 Samuel.

questions.question: What strategic action did David take after hearing that the Philistines sought him, and how does this reflect ancient warfare tactics?
options: He enquired of God before battle
questions.correctAnswer: He enquired of God before battle
questions.explanation: Verse 10 shows David's practice of seeking divine guidance before engaging in battle, a common theme in Israelite warfare reflecting reliance on God’s will rather than solely human strategy.

questions.question: The place where David defeated the Philistines the first time was named Baalperazim. What does this name mean and what is its literary significance?
questions.correctAnswer: Lord of breakthroughs
questions.explanation: In verse 11, David names the location Baalperazim, meaning 'Lord of breakthroughs,' metaphorically illustrating God's powerful intervention likened to a sudden flood breaking forth, highlighting divine agency in victory.

questions.question: After the Philistines left their gods behind following their defeat, what did David order to be done with them, and what does this imply about Israelite attitudes toward idolatry?
options: They were returned to the Philistines
They were hidden in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They were burned with fire
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states David commanded that the Philistine gods left behind be burned, reflecting Israel’s rejection of idolatry and the purging of foreign religious influences.

questions.question: What specific instruction did God give David for his second encounter with the Philistines, and how does this illustrate the theme of divine guidance?
options: Do not pursue them, but attack by mulberry trees
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pursue them, but attack by mulberry trees
questions.explanation: In verses 14-15, God instructs David to avoid direct pursuit and wait for a signal by the sound in the mulberry trees, demonstrating precise divine control over battle strategy.

questions.question: The victory of David over the Philistines extended from Gibeon to which other location, and what might this signify about Israel's territorial control at the time?
questions.correctAnswer: Gazer
questions.explanation: Verse 16 mentions the Philistines were defeated from Gibeon to Gazer, implying a wide range of military success and consolidation of territory in the central hill country region.

questions.question: What effect did David's victories have on his reputation among surrounding nations, according to 1 Chronicles 14?
options: The LORD brought the fear of him upon all nations
He was ignored by other kings
He was mocked by the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD brought the fear of him upon all nations
questions.explanation: Verse 17 emphasizes that David’s fame spread broadly and the LORD caused fear of him among nations, underscoring the theological theme of divine empowerment and international recognition of Israel’s king.

questions.question: True or False: David’s inquiry to God before battle in 1 Chronicles 14 reflects a pattern also seen in his earlier military decisions in 2 Samuel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David’s seeking divine guidance before battle is consistent with accounts in 2 Samuel (e.g., 2 Samuel 5:19), showing a pattern of dependence on God’s direction.

questions.question: The name 'Baalperazim' given by David after his victory is an example of which literary device commonly used in the Hebrew Bible?
questions.correctAnswer: Toponymy
questions.explanation: Naming a place based on an event, as in verse 11, is toponymy, a device frequently used in the Hebrew Bible to commemorate divine acts and shape collective memory.

questions.question: How does the sending of masons and carpenters from Tyre to David in 1 Chronicles 14:1 foreshadow later biblical themes about the temple construction?
options: It signals David’s disinterest in construction
It shows David building his own temple
It relates to the Exodus tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates Solomon's temple building
questions.explanation: The involvement of Tyrian craftsmen in 1 Chronicles 14:1 foreshadows the later construction of Solomon’s temple (1 Kings 5), highlighting a continuity in royal and religious building projects.

questions.question: David's multiplication of wives and children in Jerusalem (verses 3-7) reflects which broader biblical theme about kingship and family in ancient Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Establishing dynastic legitimacy
questions.explanation: David’s many offspring in Jerusalem helped secure a royal lineage and political alliances, a common practice in ancient Near Eastern monarchies to legitimize and stabilize dynasties.

questions.question: What is the significance of David receiving cedar timber from the king of Tyre in the context of Israel’s relations with neighboring states?
options: It indicates peaceful alliances and trade
It was a bribe to prevent war
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates peaceful alliances and trade
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows that David maintained diplomatic relations with Tyre, receiving valuable building materials, which reflects a period of peace and cooperation between Israel and Phoenicia.

questions.question: The repeated inquiries of David to God before battle (verses 10 and 14) demonstrate what theological principle emphasized throughout the Chronicler’s work?
options: Dependence on divine guidance for success
questions.correctAnswer: Dependence on divine guidance for success
questions.explanation: The Chronicler emphasizes that Israel's success depends on God’s guidance, as seen in David seeking the LORD’s counsel before battles (verses 10 and 14).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does the sending of cedar timber and skilled workers by Hiram king of Tyre to David symbolize about God's providence in David's reign?
options: Divine confirmation and provision for the establishment of God's temple
Political alliance unrelated to God's plan
A mere trade agreement with no spiritual significance
A sign of David's military dominance
questions.correctAnswer: Divine confirmation and provision for the establishment of God's temple
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:1 describes Hiram sending materials and craftsmen to David, which symbolizes God's providential provision. This parallels God's provision for temple building in Exodus 25:8-9 and 1 Kings 5:1-12, showing God orchestrates resources for His purposes. It also anticipates the Messianic temple (John 2:19-21) and God's covenant faithfulness (Psalm 78:72).

questions.question: How does David's perception of his kingdom being 'lifted up on high' reflect the theological understanding of kingship in Israel?
options: It indicates God's sovereign blessing and exaltation of David's rule
It shows David's pride and self-exaltation
It reflects success purely from military conquest
It is a metaphor for political popularity
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates God's sovereign blessing and exaltation of David's rule
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:2 states David recognized God confirmed him king, lifting his kingdom. This reflects the biblical doctrine of divine kingship where God raises and establishes rulers (Psalm 2:6-9; Daniel 2:21; Romans 13:1-2). It contrasts worldly power with God-ordained authority, emphasizing God's sovereignty over human affairs.

questions.question: Which theological theme is reflected in David taking more wives and having more children in Jerusalem?
options: The continuation of David's dynasty as part of God's covenant plan
A condemnation of polygamy as sin
A political strategy without spiritual significance
An indication of David's moral failure
questions.correctAnswer: The continuation of David's dynasty as part of God's covenant plan
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:3-7 shows David fathering many children, emphasizing the fulfillment of God's promise to make David's house enduring (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Psalm 89:3-4). This underlines the messianic hope fulfilled in Christ, a descendant of David (Luke 1:32-33; Romans 1:3). While polygamy is complex, this passage focuses on dynasty continuation.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT one of David's sons born in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar
questions.explanation: Verses 4-7 list David's sons: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpalet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphalet. Eleazar is not mentioned here. This highlights the specific lineage important for biblical genealogy and messianic prophecy (Matthew 1:6-16).

questions.question: What was the immediate military consequence when the Philistines heard David was anointed king over all Israel?
options: The Philistines gathered to seek David and fought him
David made peace with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines gathered to seek David and fought him
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:8-9 shows the Philistines gathering in the valley of Rephaim to confront David, indicating opposition to God's anointed king. This reflects the biblical theme of spiritual and political opposition to God's kingdom (Isaiah 49:25; Acts 13:47-49). God's people often face adversaries at significant moments in redemptive history.

questions.question: What does David's inquiry of God before battle teach about the role of divine guidance in leadership?
options: Leaders must seek God's direction to ensure success
God's guidance is optional for leaders
David was uncertain and lacked faith
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must seek God's direction to ensure success
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:10 and 14 show David asking God whether to attack, receiving clear instructions. This emphasizes dependence on divine wisdom (Proverbs 3:5-6; James 1:5), illustrating that godly leadership requires communion with God for guidance and victory (Exodus 17:8-13; Judges 7:2-7).

questions.question: Why did David name the place Baalperazim after his victory over the Philistines?
options: Because God broke in upon his enemies like breaking waters
Because it was the name of the valley
Because David built an altar there
questions.correctAnswer: Because God broke in upon his enemies like breaking waters
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:11 explains the name Baalperazim means 'Lord of Breakings Forth,' commemorating God's powerful intervention. This illustrates God's attribute as a warrior and deliverer (Exodus 15:3; Psalm 18:16-19; Isaiah 59:1-2), reinforcing trust in divine salvation rather than human might.

questions.question: What theological significance is found in David commanding the burning of the Philistine gods left behind after battle?
options: It demonstrates the rejection of idolatry and God's supremacy
It was a political act to intimidate enemies
It was a ritual to appease the gods
It was an act of revenge for past defeats
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates the rejection of idolatry and God's supremacy
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:12 shows David burned the Philistine idols, affirming theological monotheism and God's exclusive lordship (Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 7:25-26; 1 Corinthians 10:14). This act condemns idolatry and underscores God's holiness and justice.

questions.question: How did God instruct David to respond to the Philistines' second positioning in the valley?
options: Not to pursue but to ambush near the mulberry trees
To attack immediately with full force
questions.correctAnswer: Not to pursue but to ambush near the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:14-15 records God instructing David to not follow but to wait for a sign before attacking. This reveals God's strategic sovereignty in battle (Exodus 14:13-14; Judges 7:15-22), teaching reliance on divine timing and guidance rather than human impulse.

questions.question: What was the sign David was to wait for before attacking the Philistines the second time?
options: The sound of movement in the tops of the mulberry trees
questions.correctAnswer: The sound of movement in the tops of the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:15 specifies God would signal by the sound of movement in the trees, illustrating God's sovereign control over nature and events (Psalm 29:3-9; Mark 4:39). This teaches believers to discern God's specific guidance and timing.

questions.question: What was the extent of David’s victory over the Philistines following God’s guidance?
options: Only within the valley of Rephaim
Throughout the entire land of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: From Gibeon to Gazer
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:16 states David defeated the Philistines from Gibeon to Gazer, highlighting the comprehensive nature of God's deliverance in battle (Joshua 10:1-5; Judges 1:29; 2 Samuel 5:20). This echoes God's promise to give the land to His people (Deuteronomy 11:24).

questions.question: How did David's military victories affect his reputation among the nations, according to this chapter?
options: His fame spread, and the LORD caused fear of him among all nations
He was ignored by other nations
His fame was limited to Israel only
questions.correctAnswer: His fame spread, and the LORD caused fear of him among all nations
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 14:17 states David’s fame spread and God instilled fear of him across nations, reflecting the biblical theme of God exalting His anointed servant (Psalm 89:19-20; Isaiah 11:1-5; Romans 15:12). This foreshadows Christ's universal reign and respect.

questions.question: What attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated by His delivering David's enemies into his hand?
options: God's sovereignty and power over nations
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty and power over nations
questions.explanation: Throughout 1 Chronicles 14:10-11, God's delivering David's enemies shows His sovereign control over history and nations (Psalm 47:8-9; Isaiah 45:1-7; Daniel 4:17; Romans 8:28). This affirms that God governs all human events for His purposes.

questions.question: How does David's practice of consulting God before battle contribute to the doctrine of divine providence?
options: It demonstrates that God actively guides and sustains His people
It suggests that God is distant and uninvolved
It means human effort is irrelevant
It implies God only intervenes occasionally
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates that God actively guides and sustains His people
questions.explanation: David’s inquiries in 1 Chronicles 14:10 and 14 highlight the doctrine of providence where God not only created but continually directs His creation (Psalm 37:23; Proverbs 16:9; Hebrews 1:3; Matthew 10:29-31). This reassures believers of God's intimate involvement in their lives.

questions.question: What messianic theme is implied by the establishment of David's kingdom and his victories in this chapter?
options: The foreshadowing of Christ’s universal kingship and victory over evil
The ultimate failure of human kingship
The temporary nature of Israel’s monarchy
The irrelevance of David’s reign to salvation history
questions.correctAnswer: The foreshadowing of Christ’s universal kingship and victory over evil
questions.explanation: David’s anointed kingship and triumphs (1 Chronicles 14:2,17) prefigure the Messiah who reigns eternally and defeats all enemies (Psalm 110:1-2; Isaiah 9:6-7; Revelation 19:11-16). This chapter fits into the biblical narrative of redemption culminating in Christ.
